service:
Network Flow Monitor is a feature of Amazon CloudWatch Network Monitoring that provides visibility into the performance of network flows for your Amazon Web Services workloads, between instances in subnets, as well as to and from Amazon Web Services. Lightweight agents that you install on the instances capture performance metrics for your network flows, such as packet loss and latency, and send them to the Network Flow Monitor backend. Then, you can view and analyze metrics from the top contributors for each metric type, to help troubleshoot issues.

In addition, when you create a monitor, Network Flow Monitor provides a network health indicator (NHI) that informs you whether there were Amazon Web Services network issues for one or more of the network flows tracked by a monitor, during a time period that you choose. By using this value, you can independently determine if the Amazon Web Services network is impacting your workload during a specific time frame, to help you focus troubleshooting efforts.

To learn more about Network Flow Monitor, see the Network Flow Monitor User Guide in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.

operations.CreateMonitor: Create a monitor for specific network flows between local and remote resources, so that you can monitor network performance for one or several of your workloads. For each monitor, Network Flow Monitor publishes detailed end-to-end performance metrics and a network health indicators (NHI) that informs you whether there were Amazon Web Services network issues for one or more of the network flows tracked by a monitor, during a time period that you choose.
operations.CreateScope:
Create a scope of resources that you want to be available for Network Flow Monitor to generate metrics for, when you have active agents on those resources sending metrics reports to the Network Flow Monitor backend. This call returns a scope ID to identify the scope.

When you create a scope, you enable permissions for Network Flow Monitor. The scope is set to the resources for the Amazon Web Services that enables the feature.
operations.DeleteMonitor: Deletes a monitor in Network Flow Monitor.
operations.DeleteScope: Deletes a scope that has been defined.
operations.GetMonitor: Gets information about a monitor in Network Flow Monitor based on a monitor name. The information returned includes the Amazon Resource Name (ARN), create time, modified time, resources included in the monitor, and status information.
operations.GetQueryResultsMonitorTopContributors:
Return the data for a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. You specify the query that you want to return results for by providing a query ID and a monitor name. This query returns the top contributors for a specific monitor.

Create a query ID for this call by calling the corresponding API call to start the query, StartQueryMonitorTopContributors. Use the scope ID that was returned for your account by CreateScope.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.
operations.GetQueryResultsWorkloadInsightsTopContri:
Return the data for a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. You specify the query that you want to return results for by providing a query ID and a monitor name. This query returns the top contributors for a specific monitor.

Create a query ID for this call by calling the corresponding API call to start the query, StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributors. Use the scope ID that was returned for your account by CreateScope.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

Return the data for a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to return results for by providing a query ID and a scope ID. This query returns data for the top contributors for workload insights. Workload insights provide a high level view of network flow performance data collected by agents for a scope.

Create a query ID for this call by calling the corresponding API call to start the query, StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributorsData. Use the scope ID that was returned for your account by CreateScope.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

The top contributor network flows overall for a specific metric type, for example, the number of retransmissions.
operations.GetQueryStatusMonitorTopContributors:
Returns the current status of a query for the Network Flow Monitor query interface, for a specified query ID and monitor. This call returns the query status for the top contributors for a monitor.

When you start a query, use this call to check the status of the query to make sure that it has has SUCCEEDED before you review the results. Use the same query ID that you used for the corresponding API call to start the query, StartQueryMonitorTopContributors.

When you run a query, use this call to check the status of the query to make sure that the query has SUCCEEDED before you review the results.
operations.GetQueryStatusWorkloadInsightsTopContrib:
Return the data for a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to return results for by providing a query ID and a monitor name. This query returns the top contributors for workload insights.

When you start a query, use this call to check the status of the query to make sure that it has has SUCCEEDED before you review the results. Use the same query ID that you used for the corresponding API call to start the query, StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributors.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

Returns the current status of a query for the Network Flow Monitor query interface, for a specified query ID and monitor. This call returns the query status for the top contributors data for workload insights.

When you start a query, use this call to check the status of the query to make sure that it has has SUCCEEDED before you review the results. Use the same query ID that you used for the corresponding API call to start the query, StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributorsData.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

The top contributor network flows overall for a specific metric type, for example, the number of retransmissions.
operations.GetScope: Gets information about a scope, including the name, status, tags, and target details. The scope in Network Flow Monitor is an account.
operations.ListMonitors: List all monitors in an account. Optionally, you can list only monitors that have a specific status, by using the STATUS parameter.
operations.ListScopes: List all the scopes for an account.
operations.ListTagsForResource: Returns all the tags for a resource.
operations.StartQueryMonitorTopContributors:
Start a query to return the data with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to return results for by providing a query ID and a monitor name. This query returns the top contributors for a specific monitor.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.
operations.StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributor:
Start a query to return the data with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to start by providing a query ID and a monitor name. This query returns the top contributors for a specific monitor.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

Return the data for a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to return results for by providing a query ID and a scope ID. This query returns data for the top contributors for workload insights. Workload insights provide a high level view of network flow performance data collected by agents for a scope.

A query ID is returned from an API call to start a query of a specific type; for example

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

The top contributor network flows overall for a specific metric type, for example, the number of retransmissions.
operations.StopQueryMonitorTopContributors:
Stop a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to stop by providing a query ID and a monitor name. This query returns the top contributors for a specific monitor.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.
operations.StopQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributors:
Stop a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to stop by providing a query ID and a monitor name. This query returns the top contributors for a specific monitor.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

Return the data for a query with the Network Flow Monitor query interface. Specify the query that you want to return results for by providing a query ID and a scope ID. This query returns data for the top contributors for workload insights. Workload insights provide a high level view of network flow performance data collected by agents for a scope.

Top contributors in Network Flow Monitor are network flows with the highest values for a specific metric type, related to a scope (for workload insights) or a monitor.

The top contributor network flows overall for a specific metric type, for example, the number of retransmissions.
operations.UpdateMonitor: Update a monitor to add or remove local or remote resources.
operations.UpdateScope: Update a scope to add or remove resources that you want to be available for Network Flow Monitor to generate metrics for, when you have active agents on those resources sending metrics reports to the Network Flow Monitor backend.

AccessDeniedException.base: You don't have sufficient permission to perform this action.

refs.TargetId$accountId: The identifier for the account for a target.
refs.WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsRow$accou: The account ID for a specific row of data.

refs.CreateMonitorInput$scopeArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scope for the monitor.
refs.CreateScopeOutput$scopeArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scope.
refs.GetScopeOutput$scopeArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scope.
refs.ListTagsForResourceInput$resourceArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource.
refs.ScopeSummary$scopeArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scope.
refs.TagResourceInput$resourceArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource.
refs.TraversedComponent$componentArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a tranversed component.
refs.UntagResourceInput$resourceArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource.
refs.UpdateScopeOutput$scopeArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scope.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$localAz: The Availability Zone for the local resource for a top contributor network flow.
refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$remoteAz: The Availability Zone for the remote resource for a top contributor network flow.
refs.WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsRow$local: The identifier for the Availability Zone where the local resource is located.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$localRegion: The Amazon Web Services Region for the local resource for a top contributor network flow.
refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$remoteRegion: The Amazon Web Services Region for the remote resource for a top contributor network flow.
refs.TargetResource$region: The Amazon Web Services Region where the target resource is located.
refs.WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsRow$local: The Amazon Web Services Region where the local resource is located.

refs.TraversedComponent$componentType: The type of component that was traversed.

refs.CreateMonitorInput$localResources: The local resources to monitor. A local resource, in a bi-directional flow of a workload, is the host where the agent is installed. For example, if a workload consists of an interaction between a web service and a backend database (for example, Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS)), the EC2 instance hosting the web service, which also runs the agent, is the local resource.

refs.CreateScopeInput$targets: The targets to define the scope to be monitored. Currently, a target is an Amazon Web Services account.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$destinationCat:
The destination category for a top contributors row. Destination categories can be one of the following:

  • INTRA_AZ: Top contributor network flows within a single Availability Zone

  • INTER_AZ: Top contributor network flows between Availability Zones

  • INTER_VPC: Top contributor network flows between VPCs

  • AWS_SERVICES: Top contributor network flows to or from Amazon Web Services services

  • UNCLASSIFIED: Top contributor network flows that do not have a bucket classification
refs.StartQueryMonitorTopContributorsInput$de:
The category that you want to query top contributors for, for a specific monitor. Destination categories can be one of the following:

  • INTRA_AZ: Top contributor network flows within a single Availability Zone

  • INTER_AZ: Top contributor network flows between Availability Zones

  • INTER_VPC: Top contributor network flows between VPCs

  • AWS_SERVICES: Top contributor network flows to or from Amazon Web Services services

  • UNCLASSIFIED: Top contributor network flows that do not have a bucket classification
refs.StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributor:
The destination category for a top contributors. Destination categories can be one of the following:

  • INTRA_AZ: Top contributor network flows within a single Availability Zone

  • INTER_AZ: Top contributor network flows between Availability Zones

  • INTER_VPC: Top contributor network flows between VPCs

  • AWS_SERVICES: Top contributor network flows to or from Amazon Web Services services

  • UNCLASSIFIED: Top contributor network flows that do not have a bucket classification

The destination category for a top contributors row. Destination categories can be one of the following:

  • INTRA_AZ: Top contributor network flows within a single Availability Zone

  • INTER_AZ: Top contributor network flows between Availability Zones

  • INTER_VPC: Top contributor network flows between VPCs

  • AWS_SERVICES: Top contributor network flows to or from Amazon Web Services services

  • UNCLASSIFIED: Top contributor network flows that do not have a bucket classification

refs.GetScopeInput$scopeId: The identifier for the scope that includes the resources you want to get data results for. A scope ID is an internally-generated identifier that includes all the resources for a specific root account. A scope ID is returned from a CreateScope API call.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$localInstanceA: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a local resource.
refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$remoteInstance: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a remote resource.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$localInstanceI: The instance identifier for the local resource for a top contributor network flow.
refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$remoteInstance: The instance identifier for the remote resource for a top contributor network flow.

refs.GetQueryResultsMonitorTopContributorsInp: The number of query results that you want to return with this call.
refs.GetQueryResultsWorkloadInsightsTopContri: The number of query results that you want to return with this call.
The number of query results that you want to return with this call.

refs.CreateMonitorOutput$createdAt: The date and time when the monitor was created.
refs.CreateMonitorOutput$modifiedAt: The last date and time that the monitor was modified.
refs.GetMonitorOutput$createdAt: The date and time when the monitor was created.
refs.GetMonitorOutput$modifiedAt: The date and time when the monitor was last modified.
refs.UpdateMonitorOutput$createdAt: The date and time when the monitor was created.
refs.UpdateMonitorOutput$modifiedAt: The last date and time that the monitor was modified.

refs.StartQueryMonitorTopContributorsInput$li: The maximum number of top contributors to return.
refs.StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributor: The maximum number of top contributors to return.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$value: The value of the metric for a top contributor network flow.

refs.ListMonitorsInput$maxResults: The number of query results that you want to return with this call.
refs.ListScopesInput$maxResults: The number of query results that you want to return with this call.

refs.GetQueryResultsMonitorTopContributorsOut: The units for a metric returned by the query.
refs.GetQueryResultsWorkloadInsightsTopContri: The units for a metric returned by the query.

refs.CreateMonitorOutput$monitorArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the monitor.
refs.GetMonitorOutput$monitorArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the monitor.
refs.MonitorSummary$monitorArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the monitor.
refs.UpdateMonitorOutput$monitorArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the monitor.

refs.ListMonitorsOutput$monitors: The monitors that are in an account.

MonitorLocalResource.base: A local resource is the host where the agent is installed. Local resources can be a a subnet, a VPC, or an Availability Zone.

refs.MonitorLocalResource$type: The type of the local resource. Valid values are AWS::EC2::VPC AWS::AvailabilityZone or AWS::EC2::Subnet.

refs.CreateMonitorOutput$localResources: The local resources to monitor. A local resource, in a bi-directional flow of a workload, is the host where the agent is installed.
refs.UpdateMonitorInput$localResourcesToAdd: The local resources to add, as an array of resources with identifiers and types.
refs.UpdateMonitorInput$localResourcesToRemov: The local resources to remove, as an array of resources with identifiers and types.
refs.UpdateMonitorOutput$localResources: The local resources updated for a monitor, as an array of resources with identifiers and types.

refs.StartQueryMonitorTopContributorsInput$me: The metric that you want to query top contributors for. That is, you can specify this metric to return the top contributor network flows, for this type of metric, for a monitor and (optionally) within a specific category, such as network flows between Availability Zones.

MonitorRemoteResource.base: A remote resource is the other endpoint in a network flow. That is, one endpoint is the local resource and the other is the remote resource. Remote resources can be a a subnet, a VPC, an Availability Zone, or an Amazon Web Services service.

refs.MonitorRemoteResource$type: The type of the remote resource. Valid values are AWS::EC2::VPC AWS::AvailabilityZone, AWS::EC2::Subnet, or AWS::AWSService.

refs.CreateMonitorInput$remoteResources: The remote resources to monitor. A remote resource is the other endpoint in the bi-directional flow of a workload, with a local resource. For example, Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS) can be a remote resource.
refs.CreateMonitorOutput$remoteResources: The remote resources to monitor. A remote resource is the other endpoint in the bi-directional flow of a workload, with a local resource. For example, Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS) can be a remote resource. The remote resource is identified by its ARN or an identifier.
refs.UpdateMonitorInput$remoteResourcesToAdd: The remove resources to add, as an array of resources with identifiers and types.
refs.UpdateMonitorInput$remoteResourcesToRemo: The remove resources to remove, as an array of resources with identifiers and types.
refs.UpdateMonitorOutput$remoteResources: The remote resources updated for a monitor, as an array of resources with identifiers and types.

refs.CreateMonitorOutput$monitorStatus:
The status of a monitor. The status can be one of the following

  • PENDING: The monitor is in the process of being created.

  • ACTIVE: The monitor is active.

  • INACTIVE: The monitor is inactive.

  • ERROR: Monitor creation failed due to an error.

  • DELETING: The monitor is in the process of being deleted.
refs.GetMonitorOutput$monitorStatus:
The status of a monitor. The status can be one of the following

  • PENDING: The monitor is in the process of being created.

  • ACTIVE: The monitor is active.

  • INACTIVE: The monitor is inactive.

  • ERROR: Monitor creation failed due to an error.

  • DELETING: The monitor is in the process of being deleted.
refs.ListMonitorsInput$monitorStatus:
The status of a monitor. The status can be one of the following

  • PENDING: The monitor is in the process of being created.

  • ACTIVE: The monitor is active.

  • INACTIVE: The monitor is inactive.

  • ERROR: Monitor creation failed due to an error.

  • DELETING: The monitor is in the process of being deleted.
refs.MonitorSummary$monitorStatus:
The status of a monitor. The status can be one of the following

  • PENDING: The monitor is in the process of being created.

  • ACTIVE: The monitor is active.

  • INACTIVE: The monitor is inactive.

  • ERROR: Monitor creation failed due to an error.

  • DELETING: The monitor is in the process of being deleted.
refs.UpdateMonitorOutput$monitorStatus:
The status of a monitor. The status can be one of the following

  • PENDING: The monitor is in the process of being created.

  • ACTIVE: The monitor is active.

  • INACTIVE: The monitor is inactive.

  • ERROR: Monitor creation failed due to an error.

  • DELETING: The monitor is in the process of being deleted.

MonitorSummary.base: A summary of information about a monitor, includ the ARN, the name, and the status.

MonitorTopContributorsRow.base: A set of information for a top contributor network flow in a monitor. In a monitor, Network Flow Monitor returns information about the network flows for top contributors for each metric. Top contributors are network flows with the top values for each metric type.

refs.GetQueryResultsMonitorTopContributorsOut: The top contributor network flows overall for a specific metric type, for example, the number of retransmissions.

refs.GetQueryStatusMonitorTopContributorsOutp:
When you run a query, use this call to check the status of the query to make sure that the query has SUCCEEDED before you review the results.

  • QUEUED: The query is scheduled to run.

  • RUNNING: The query is in progress but not complete.

  • SUCCEEDED: The query completed sucessfully.

  • FAILED: The query failed due to an error.

  • CANCELED: The query was canceled.
refs.GetQueryStatusWorkloadInsightsTopContrib:
The status of a query for top contributors data.

  • QUEUED: The query is scheduled to run.

  • RUNNING: The query is in progress but not complete.

  • SUCCEEDED: The query completed sucessfully.

  • FAILED: The query failed due to an error.

  • CANCELED: The query was canceled.

When you run a query, use this call to check the status of the query to make sure that the query has SUCCEEDED before you review the results.

  • QUEUED: The query is scheduled to run.

  • RUNNING: The query is in progress but not complete.

  • SUCCEEDED: The query completed sucessfully.

  • FAILED: The query failed due to an error.

  • CANCELED: The query was canceled.

refs.DeleteMonitorInput$monitorName: The name of the monitor to delete.

ResourceNotFoundException.base: The request specifies a resource that doesn't exist.

refs.CreateScopeOutput$status: The status for a call to create a scope. The status can be one of the following: SUCCEEDED, IN_PROGRESS, or FAILED.
refs.GetScopeOutput$status: The status of a scope. The status can be one of the following: SUCCEEDED, IN_PROGRESS, or FAILED.
refs.ScopeSummary$status: The status of a scope. The status can be one of the following, depending on the state of scope creation: SUCCEEDED, IN_PROGRESS, or FAILED.
refs.UpdateScopeOutput$status: The status for a call to update a scope. The status can be one of the following: SUCCEEDED, IN_PROGRESS, or FAILED.

ScopeSummary.base: A summary of information about a scope, including the ARN, target ID, and Amazon Web Services Region.

refs.CreateMonitorInput$tags: The tags for a monitor. You can add a maximum of 200 tags.
refs.CreateScopeInput$tags: The tags for a scope. You can add a maximum of 200 tags.

TargetId.base: A target ID is an internally-generated identifier for a target. A target allows you to identify all the resources in a Network Flow Monitor scope. Currently, a target is always an Amazon Web Services account.

TargetIdentifier.base: A target identifier is a pair of identifying information for a resource that is included in a target. A target identifier includes the target ID and the target type.

refs.TargetResource$targetIdentifier: A target identifier is a pair of identifying information for a resource that is included in a target. A target identifier includes the target ID and the target type.

TargetResource.base: A target resource in a scope. The resource is identified by a Region and a target identifier, which includes a target ID and a target type.

refs.TargetIdentifier$targetType: The type of a target. A target type is currently always ACCOUNT because a target is currently a single Amazon Web Services account.

ThrottlingException.base: The request was denied due to request throttling.

TraversedComponent.base: A section of the network that a network flow has traveled through.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$traversedConst: The constructs traversed by a network flow.

refs.UpdateScopeInput$resourcesToAdd: A list of resources to add to a scope.

refs.UpdateScopeInput$resourcesToDelete: A list of resources to delete from a scope.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$localVpcArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a local VPC.
refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$remoteVpcArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a remote VPC.
refs.WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsRow$local: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a local VPC.

refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$localVpcId: The VPC ID for a top contributor network flow for the local resource.
refs.MonitorTopContributorsRow$remoteVpcId: The VPC ID for a top contributor network flow for the remote resource.
refs.WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsRow$local: The identifier for the VPC for the local resource.

refs.StartQueryWorkloadInsightsTopContributor: The metric that you want to query top contributors for. That is, you can specify this metric to return the top contributor network flows, for this type of metric, for a monitor and (optionally) within a specific category, such as network flows between Availability Zones.

The metric that you want to query top contributors for. That is, you can specify this metric to return the top contributor network flows, for this type of metric, for a monitor and (optionally) within a specific category, such as network flows between Availability Zones.

WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsDataPoint.base: A data point for a top contributor network flow in a scope. Network Flow Monitor returns information about the network flows with the top values for each metric type, which are called top contributors.

WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsRow.base: A row for a top contributor for a scope.

refs.GetQueryResultsWorkloadInsightsTopContri: The top contributor network flows overall for a specific metric type, for example, the number of retransmissions.

refs.WorkloadInsightsTopContributorsDataPoint: An array of the timestamps for the data point.
